channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Attention, Perl programmers. We’re looking for those among you who loved their childhood chemistry sets and could spend hours studying their ant farms. Science buffs and genetics junkies, our client wants to hear from you. They deliver cost-efficient genotyping technology that promotes the development of better, stronger crops adapted to suit their environment.

item.title: Smart Shopper = Smart Saver. Perl role in Vienna
item.description: As one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries, they share your dedication to finding consumers the best possible deal on electronics, technology, household appliances, and gaming systems. Best of all, they’re looking for a Perl programmer. - PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: Join Our Merry Band of Perl Programmers
item.description: The role in our client's Belarus office offers a unique opportunity to join an established company in a new office. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Mad Men (and women) of London. Perl in London
item.description: The leader in premium native advertising for technology, financial services, and corporate and lifestyle sectors, our client is the power behind the advertising throne for over 200 websites, including Forbes, Wall Street Journal, CNN Business, and The Washington Post. This dynamic team is looking for a senior Perl programmer.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: With over 15 million applications per month funnelling through their channels, our client is at the top of their industry and — lucky you — they’re looking for a Perl programmer to join their team. Not feeling the urge to commute during these socially distanced times and beyond? Not a problem. The role is 100% remote-friendly for folks in the UK.

item.title: Live Video - Ordered Letters by Mohammad Anwar
Weekly Challenge 112
item.description: Simon approached the Climb Stairs task in a very fun way. Loved it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112: Canonical Stairs
item.description: Roger shared simple but concise solution to the Canonical Path task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112: Climbing the canonical path!
item.description: Luca attempted to solve the Climb Stairs task without the use of any library, pure logical solution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112
item.description: Luis use of regex is very different from others. You must take a look.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112: Canonical Path and Climb Stairs
item.description: Laurent shared something new try-steps for the Climb Stairs. Thanks for shairing the magic of Raku.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #112
item.description: James is unbeatable when it comes to performance analysis. What an honour to have him in the team.

item.title: PWC112 - Climb Stairs
item.description: Flavio shared very interesting story and unique algorithm. Well done. Keep it up.

item.title: PWC112 - Canonical Path
item.description: Flavio presented a very concise regex solution to the Canonical Path task. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: One Step Beyond: Perl Weekly Challenge #112
item.description: Dave's used the power of regex when dealing with canonical Path task.

item.title: After Finding Our Bearings: One, Two and Up We Go!
item.description: Colin's dealing with the Climb Stairs task is very interesting. Loved his task analysis.

item.title: Canonical Stairs with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne shared Perl and Raku solutions both this week. Raku solution to the Canonical Path task is my favourite.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 112
item.description: Adam presented cute modularised solution to this week challenges. Nice work, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112: Climb Stairs
item.description: Abigail took us to another journey whilst dealing with Climb Stairs task. It took more than one readings to get the logic.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112: Canonical Path
item.description: Abigail approach to Canonical Path task is simply elegant. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112
item.description: Aaron's style of analysis is very interesting and makes even difficult task looks simple. Well done.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 112
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Canonical Path" and "Climb Stairs" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 113
item.description: Welcome to a new week with couple of fun tasks "Represent Integer" and "Recreate Binary Tree". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Complexity ramblings
item.description: Thank you Flavio for the detailed discussion on the subject.

item.title: A Perl Community Dashboard
item.description: In the recent TPF Marketing Committee meeting, Dean proposed the plan for community dashboard.

item.title: Tools for learning Perl context
item.description: Interesting discussion about the Perl context switching.

item.title: Testing Perl: To plan or not to plan
item.description: Mark continued his blog series and this time he is talking about test plans.

item.title: Please delete your old releases from CPAN!
item.description: Neil appeal to all CPAN module author to clean up their old releases from CPAN.

item.title: The support developers need - survey results and actions taken
item.description: Andrew presenting the survey results and action taken based on the result.

item.title: Perl is part of Google's Season of Docs 2021
item.description: Jason announced the good news that Perl is now part of GSOD 2021.

item.title: #512 - Celebration Time
item.description:
Hi there

Happy Idd to all the readers of the newsletter.

We should try to avoid all the negativities around us and focus on every little success stories. I know it is not easy but we shouldn't give up without a fight. Now a days social media platform plays vital role in spreading the news. So if you do come across any success story please do share with the community. It helps as morale booster.

I would like to specially mention two stories this week, Andrew Solomon survey result and the action taken and Dean proposed community dashboard. Kudos to Andrew and Dean for taking the initiative. Keep it up.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
